messageBody:
Hi Adrian,

Interesting approach... I have two remarks:

1) I find it a bit odd that inside a class Stack, you find yourself creating
a brand new instance of Stack and passing it around, instead of just reusing
the same instance (I realize it's because JUnit creates a new instance
before each test, but this doesn't strike me as optimal)

2) Your current implementation will break if a method gets renamed, which is
why, while TestNG supports direct method dependencies with
@Test(dependsOnMethods), I highly recommend using group dependencies
instead:

class Stack {
@Test(groups = "populate")
public void pushShouldPopulate() {
...
}

@Test(dependsOnGroups = "populate")
public void popShouldReturnTopElement() {
...
}
}

The advantage of this approach is that it is independent of method names
("refactoring safe"") and it captures the fact that any test method that
populates the stack is a valid prerequisite to testing pop(). In other
words, you can add more methods to the group "populate" and everything will
work as long as all these methods leave the stack populated with at least
one element.

Anyway, I'm glad to see test dependencies receive the attention they deserve
:-)

--
Cédric

On Sat, May 3, 2008 at 10:09 PM, adrian.kuhn <adrian.kuhn@...> wrote:

> Welcome everyone,
>
> I am new here and hope that this is the right place to announce a novel
> JUnit extensions. If not, please point us to the proper
> place.
>
> JExample is an extensions that introduces dependencies. But unlike eg
> TestNG, we go beyond mere dependencies. We use
> dependencies to pass the "instance under test" from one the test method to
> the next. If test B depends on A, the return value of A
> can be used as B's fixture. And if A test fails, B and all other dependees
> of A are skipped and marked as white. We show in an
> empirical study (accepted at the XP2008 conference) that JExample improves
> performance, shortness of test methods, and defect
> localization.
>
> Let me give an example :)
>
> Testing a stack is not trivial, there is an intrinsic dependency between
> pushing and popping elements. An element can not be
> popped without pushing it first. Intrinsic dependencies are evil. If there
> is a bug in push, both push's and pop's test fail, even if
> there is no bug in pop! Therefore, we declare that testPop depends on the
> successful outcome of testPush. When running the
> tests, the return value of testPush is used as the fixture of testPop.
>
> @Test
> public Stack testPush() {
> Stack s = new Stack();
> s.push("Foo");
> assertEquals(1, s.size());
> return s;
> }
>
> @Test
> @Depends("testPush")
> public void testPop(Stack s) {
> s.pop("Foo");
> assertEquals(0, s.size());
> }
>
> Using JExample, each test method is a comprehensive constructor that
> creates an example instance of the unit under test. That is
> also why JExample is called JExample. The idea of example-driven testing is
> based on the work of Markus Gaelli.
>
> You can learn more about JExample here
>
> http://www.iam.unibe.ch/~akuhn/blog/2008/04/jexample-quickstart/<http://www.iam.unibe.ch/%7Eakuhn/blog/2008/04/jexample-quickstart/>
> http://www.iam.unibe.ch/~scg/Research/JExample/<http://www.iam.unibe.ch/%7Escg/Research/JExample/>
>
> Download
>
> http://www.iam.unibe.ch/~scg/Research/JExample/jexample-latest.jar<http://www.iam.unibe.ch/%7Escg/Research/JExample/jexample-latest.jar>
>
> Please give it a try (JExample is a seamless extension of JUnit and even
> runs with the normal JUnit runner of Eclipse) and let us
> know what you think.
>
> cheers,
> Adrian
